form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Grassley (for himself and Mr. Thune) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance

form.official-title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to enhance taxpayer rights, and for other purposes.

section.header: Short title, etc

subsection.text: This Act may be cited as the Taxpayer Bill of Rights Enhancement Act of 2015.

Except as otherwise expressly provided, whenever in this Act an amendment or repeal is expressed in terms of an amendment to, or repeal of, a section or other provision, the reference shall be considered to be made to a section or other provision of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
The table of contents for this Act is as follows:

title.header: Taxpayer bill of rights and Internal Revenue Service accountability

section.header: Duty to ensure that IRS employees are familiar with and act in accord with certain taxpayer rights

subsection.text: Section 7803(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by redesignating paragraph (3) as paragraph (4) and by inserting after paragraph (2) the following new paragraph:

paragraph.header: Execution of duties in accord with taxpayer rights
paragraph.text: In discharging his duties, the Commissioner shall ensure that employees of the Internal Revenue Service are familiar with and act in accord with taxpayer rights as afforded by other provisions of this title, including—

subparagraph.text: the right to be informed,
the right to quality service,
the right to pay no more than the correct amount of tax,
the right to challenge the position of the Internal Revenue Service and be heard,
the right to appeal a decision of the Internal Revenue Service in an independent forum,
the right to finality,
the right to privacy,
the right to confidentiality,
the right to retain representation, and
the right to a fair and just tax system.

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Revisions relating to termination of employment of IRS employees for misconduct

subsection.header: Termination for taking official actions for political purposes
subsection.text: Paragraph (10) of section 1203(b) of the Internal Revenue Service Restructuring and Reform Act of 1998 is amended to read as follows:

paragraph.text: performing, delaying, or failing to perform (or threatening to perform, delay, or fail to perform) any official action (including any audit) with respect to a taxpayer for purpose of extracting personal gain or benefit or for a political purpose.

subsection.header: Notification of decision not To terminate employment
subsection.text: Section 1203(c) of the Internal Revenue Service Restructuring and Reform Act of 1998 is amended by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

paragraph.text: In any case in which the Commissioner exercises the authority under paragraph (1), the Commissioner shall submit to the chairman and ranking member of the Committee on Finance of the Senate and the chairman and ranking member of the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives of the reasons for taking a personnel action other than termination.

section.header: Codification of rules for retention of Internal Revenue Service emails

subsection.text: Email records of the Internal Revenue Service shall be retained in an appropriate electronic system that supports records management and litigation requirements, including the capability to identify, retrieve, and retain the records, in accordance with this subsection:

paragraph.text: Prior to the date on which the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration makes the certification under subsection (c)(1), the Commissioner of Internal Revenue and the Chief Counsel for the Internal Revenue Service shall retain all email records.

Not later than December 31, 2016, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue and the Chief Counsel for the Internal Revenue Service shall maintain email records of all principal officers and specified employees of the Internal Revenue Service for a period of 15 years beginning on the date such record was generated.

subsection.header: Transmission of records to the National Archives
subsection.text: Not later than the last day of the 15-year period described in subsection (a)(2), the Commissioner of Internal Revenue and the Chief Counsel for the Internal Revenue Service shall transfer the email records of principal officers of the Internal Revenue Service to the Archivist of the United States.

paragraph.text: On the date that the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration determines that the Internal Revenue Service has a program in place that complies with the requirements of subsections (a)(2) and (b), the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration shall certify to the Committee on Finance of the Senate and the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives that the Internal Revenue Service is in compliance with such requirements.

subparagraph.text: Not later than March 1, 2016, the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration shall submit a report to the Committee on Finance of the Senate and the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives on the steps being taken by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue and the Chief Counsel for the Internal Revenue Service to comply with the requirements of subsections (a)(2) and (b).

Not later than March 1, 2017, the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration shall submit a report to the Committee on Finance of the Senate and the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives describing whether the Internal Revenue Service is in compliance with the requirements of subsections (a)(2) and (b).

paragraph.text: For purposes of this section, the term principal officer means, with respect to the Internal Revenue Service—

subparagraph.text: any employee whose position is listed under the Internal Revenue Service in the most recent version of the United States Government Manual published by the Office of the Federal Register,
any employee who is a senior staff member reporting directly to the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and
any—

clause.text: associate counsel, deputy counsel, or division head in the Office of the Chief Counsel for the Internal Revenue Service, and
any employee who is a senior staff member,

subparagraph.continuation-text: who reports directly to such Chief Counsel.

paragraph.text: The term specified employee means, with respect to the Internal Revenue Service, any employee who—

subparagraph.text: holds a Senior Executive Service position (as defined in section 3132 of title 5, United States Code) in the Internal Revenue Service or the Office of Chief Counsel for the Internal Revenue Service), and
is not a principal officer of the Internal Revenue Service.

section.header: Criminal penalty for unauthorized disclosure or inspection

subsection.text: Section 7213 is amended by striking $5,000 each place it appears in subsections (a) and (d) and inserting $20,000.
Section 7213A(b)(1) is amended by striking $1,000 and inserting $5,000.
The amendments made by this section shall apply to violations occurring after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Civil damages for unauthorized disclosure or inspection

subsection.text: Subsection (e) of section 7431 is amended by adding at the end the following new sentences: The Secretary shall also notify such taxpayer if the Internal Revenue Service or, upon notice to the Secretary by a Federal or State agency, if such Federal or State agency, proposes an administrative determination as to disciplinary or adverse action against an employee arising from the employee’s unauthorized inspection or disclosure of the taxpayer’s return or return information. The notice described in this subsection shall include the date of the inspection or disclosure and the rights of the taxpayer under such administrative determination..

paragraph.text: Section 7431 is amended by adding at the end the following new subsection:

subsection.text: Claims pursuant to subsection (a)(1) shall be payable out of funds appropriated under section 1304 of title 31, United States Code.

paragraph.text: The Secretary of the Treasury shall annually report to the Committee on Finance of the Senate and the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives regarding payments made from the United States Judgment Fund under section 7431(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.

subsection.header: Burden of Proof for Good Faith Exception Rests With Person Making Inspection or Disclosure
subsection.text: Section 7431(b) is amended by adding at the end the following new flush sentence:

quoted-block.quoted-block-continuation-text: In any proceeding involving the issue of the existence of good faith, the burden of proof with respect to such issue shall be on the person who made the inspection or disclosure.

subsection.text: Subsection (p) of section 6103 is amended by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

paragraph.header: Report on willful unauthorized disclosure and inspection
paragraph.text: As part of the report required by paragraph (3)(C) for each calendar year, the Secretary shall furnish information regarding the willful unauthorized disclosure and inspection of returns and return information, including the number, status, and results of—

subparagraph.text: administrative investigations,
civil lawsuits brought under section 7431 (including the amounts for which such lawsuits were settled and the amounts of damages awarded), and
criminal prosecutions.

subsection.header: Increase in amount of damages per violation

paragraph.text: Subparagraph (A) of section 7431(c)(1) is amended to read as follows:

subparagraph.text: the sum of—

clause.text: $5,000 for each act of unauthorized inspection of a return or return information with respect to which such defendant is found liable, and
$10,000 for each act of unauthorized disclosure of a return or return information with respect to which such defendant is found liable, or

subparagraph.text: Section 7431(c) is amended by redesignating paragraphs (2) and (3) as paragraphs (3) and (4), respectively, and by inserting after paragraph (1) the following new paragraph:

paragraph.text: in the case of willful inspection or disclosure or an inspection or disclosure which is the result of gross negligence, punitive damages, plus

subparagraph.text: Subparagraph (B) of section 7431(c) is amended to read as follows:
the actual damages sustained by the plaintiff as a result of such unauthorized inspection or disclosure, plus

paragraph.text: The amendment made by subsection (a) shall apply to determinations made after the date which is 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act.
The amendment made by subsection (b)(1) shall take effect on the date which is 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act.
The amendments made by subsection (c) shall apply to inspections and disclosures occurring on and after the date which is 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act.
Subsection (b)(2) and the amendment made by subsection (d) shall apply to calendar years ending after the date which is 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act.
The amendment made by subsection (e) shall apply to proceedings commenced after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: IRS employees prohibited from using personal email accounts for official business
section.text: No officer or employee of the Internal Revenue Service may use a personal email account to conduct any official business of the Government.

section.header: Compliance by contractors with confidentiality safeguards

subsection.text: Section 6103(p), as amended by this Act, is amended by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

paragraph.header: Disclosure to contractors and other agents
paragraph.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, no return or return information shall be disclosed to any contractor or other agent of a Federal, State, or local agency unless such agency, to the satisfaction of the Secretary—

subparagraph.text: has requirements in effect which require each such contractor or other agent which would have access to returns or return information to provide safeguards (within the meaning of paragraph (4)) to protect the confidentiality of such returns or return information,

agrees to conduct an on-site review every 3 years (or a mid-point review in the case of contracts or agreements of less than 3 years in duration) of each contractor or other agent to determine compliance with such requirements,
submits the findings of the most recent review conducted under subparagraph (B) to the Secretary as part of the report required by paragraph (4)(E), and
certifies to the Secretary for the most recent annual period that such contractor or other agent is in compliance with all such requirements.

paragraph.continuation-text: The certification required by subparagraph (D) shall include the name and address of each contractor and other agent, a description of the contract or agreement with such contractor or other agent, and the duration of such contract or agreement. The requirements of this paragraph shall not apply to disclosures pursuant to subsection (n) for purposes of Federal tax administration.

subsection.text: Subparagraph (B) of section 6103(p)(8) is amended by inserting or paragraph (10) after subparagraph (A).

paragraph.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply to disclosures made after the date of the enactment of this Act.

The first certification under section 6103(p)(10)(D) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as added by subsection (a), shall be made with respect to the portion of calendar year 2015 following the date of the enactment of this Act.

title.header: The right to appeal in an independent forum and to challenge the Internal Revenue Service position and be heard

section.header: Increase in limitations on civil damages for certain unauthorized collection actions

subsection.text: Section 7433(b) is amended by striking $1,000,000 ($100,000 and inserting $1,500,000 ($150,000.

subsection.header: Punitive damages in the case of reckless or intentional action
subsection.text: Subsection (b) of section 7433 is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating paragraphs (1) and (2) as subparagraphs (A) and (B), respectively, and by moving such subparagraphs 2 ems to the right,
by striking In any action and inserting the following:
In any action
by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

paragraph.header: Punitive damages for willful and reckless actions
paragraph.text: In any action brought under subsection (a) or petition filed under subsection (e) in which the defendant is found to be liable and to have acted recklessly or intentionally, the court may award the plaintiff punitive damages.

subsection.text: Paragraph (3) of section 7433(d) is amended by striking the date the right of action accrues and inserting the later of the date of on which administrative remedies available within the Internal Revenue Service have been exhausted or the date on which the taxpayer reasonably could have discovered that the actions of the officer or employee were done in disregard of a provision of this title or any regulation promulgated under this title.
The amendments made by this section shall apply in the case of proceedings commenced after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Extension of time limit for contesting IRS levy

subsection.header: Extension of Time for Return of Property Subject to Levy
subsection.text: Subsection (b) of section 6343 is amended by striking 9 months and inserting 2 years.
Subsection (c) of section 6532 is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking 9 months in paragraph (1) and inserting 2 years, and
by striking 9-month in paragraph (2) and inserting 2-year.

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply to—

paragraph.text: levies made after the date of the enactment of this Act, and
levies made on or before such date if the 9-month period has not expired under section 6343(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (without regard to this section) as of such date.

section.header: Expansion of declaratory judgment remedy to tax-exempt organizations

subsection.text: Paragraph (1) of section 7428(a) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subparagraph (B) by inserting after 509(a)) the following: or as a private operating foundation (as defined in section 4942(j)(3)); and
by amending subparagraph (C) to read as follows:

subparagraph.text: with respect to the initial qualification or continuing qualification of an organization as an organization described in section 501(c) (other than paragraph (3)) or 501(d) which is exempt from tax under section 501(a), or

subsection.text: Subsection (a) of section 7428 is amended in the material following paragraph (2) by striking United States Tax Court, the United States Claims Court, or the district court of the United States for the District of Columbia and inserting the following: United States Tax Court (in the case of any such determination or failure) or the Court of Federal Claims or the district court of the United States for the District of Columbia (in the case of a determination or failure with respect to an issue referred to in subparagraph (A), (B), or (D) of paragraph (1)),.
Section 7428, as amended by subsection (b), is amended by striking Claims Court each place it appears in subsection (a), (b)(2), and (c)(1)(C)(iii) and inserting Court of Federal Claims.
The amendments made by this section shall apply to pleadings filed after the date of the enactment of this Act.

title.header: The right to a fair and just tax system

section.header: Waiver of user fee for installment agreements using automated withdrawals

subsection.text: Section 6159 is amended by redesignating subsections (e) and (f) as subsections (f) and (g), respectively, and by inserting after subsection (d) the following new subsection:

subsection.header: Waiver of user fees for installment agreements using automated withdrawals
subsection.text: In the case of a taxpayer who enters into an installment agreement in which automated installment payments are agreed to, the Secretary shall waive the fee (if any) for entering into the installment agreement.
The amendments made by this section shall apply to agreements entered into on or after the date which is 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Individuals held harmless on improper levy on individual retirement plan

subsection.text: Section 6343 is amended by adding at the end the following new subsection:

subsection.header: Individuals Held Harmless on Wrongful Levy, etc. on Individual Retirement Plan

paragraph.text: If the Secretary determines that an individual retirement plan has been levied upon in a case to which subsection (b) or (d)(2)(A) applies and property or an amount of money is returned to the individual who is the beneficiary of such plan—

subparagraph.text: the individual may contribute such property or an amount equal to the sum of—

clause.text: the amount of money returned by the Secretary on account of such levy, and
interest paid under subsection (c) on such amount of money,

subparagraph.continuation-text: into an individual retirement plan (other than an endowment contract) to which a rollover contribution of a distribution from the plan levied upon is permitted if such contribution is made not later than the due date (not including extensions) for filing the return of tax for the taxable year in which such property or amount of money is returned, and

subparagraph.text: the Secretary shall, at the time such property or amount of money is returned, notify such individual that a contribution described in subparagraph (A) may be made.

paragraph.text: The distribution on account of the levy and any contribution under paragraph (1) with respect to such distribution shall be treated for purposes of this title as if such distribution and contribution were part of a rollover contribution described in section 408(d)(3)(A)(i); except that—

subparagraph.text: the contribution shall be treated as having been made to the individual retirement plan for the taxable year in which the distribution on account of the levy occurred, and the interest paid under subsection (c) shall be treated as earnings within such plan after the contribution and as not includible in gross income, and
such contribution shall not be taken into account under section 408(d)(3)(B).

paragraph.header: Refund, etc., of income tax on levy
paragraph.text: Except in the case of a rollover contribution under this subsection from an individual retirement plan that is not a Roth IRA to a Roth IRA, if any amount is includible in gross income for a taxable year by reason of a levy referred to in paragraph (1) and any portion of such amount is treated as a rollover contribution under paragraph (2), any tax imposed by chapter 1 on such portion shall not be assessed, and if assessed shall be abated, and if collected shall be credited or refunded as an overpayment made on the due date for filing the return of tax for such taxable year.

Notwithstanding subsection (d), interest shall be allowed under subsection (c) in a case in which the Secretary makes a determination described in subsection (d)(2)(A) with respect to a levy upon an individual retirement plan.

For purposes of paragraph (1)(A), section 408(d)(3)(C) shall be disregarded in determining whether an individual retirement plan is a plan to which a rollover contribution of a distribution from the plan levied upon is permitted.

subsection.text: The amendment made by this section shall apply to amounts paid under subsections (b), (c), and (d)(2)(A) of section 6343 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 after December 31, 2015.

section.header: Office of Chief Counsel review of offers-in-compromise

subsection.text: Section 7122(b) is amended by striking Whenever a compromise and all that follows through his delegate and inserting If the Secretary determines that an opinion of the General Counsel for the Department of the Treasury, or the Counsel’s delegate, is required with respect to a compromise, there shall be placed on file in the office of the Secretary such opinion.
Section 7122(b) is amended by striking the second and third sentences.
The amendments made by this section shall apply to offers-in-compromise submitted or pending on or after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Authority of the National Taxpayer Advocate to comment on Treasury regulations

subsection.text: Section 7805 is amended by adding at the end the following new subsection:

subsection.header: Review of impact of regulations on taxpayer rights

paragraph.text: Prior to publication of any proposed or temporary regulation by the Secretary, the Secretary shall submit such regulation to the National Taxpayer Advocate for comment on the impact of such regulation on taxpayer rights or taxpayer burden. Not later than the date 4 weeks after the date of such submission, the National Taxpayer Advocate shall submit comments, if any, on such regulation to the Secretary.
In prescribing any final regulation which supersedes a proposed or temporary regulation with respect to which the National Taxpayer Advocate has submitted comments—

subparagraph.text: the Secretary shall consider the comments of the National Taxpayer Advocate on such proposed or temporary regulation, and
the Secretary shall discuss its response to such comments in the preamble of such final regulation.

subsection.text: The amendment made by this section shall apply with respect to regulations issued after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Individual estimated tax

subsection.header: Increase in Exception for Individuals Owing Small Amount of Tax
subsection.text: Section 6654(e)(1) is amended by striking $1,000 and inserting $2,000.
Section 6654 is amended by striking subsections (a) and (b) and inserting the following:

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, in the case of any underpayment of estimated tax by an individual for a taxable year, there shall be added to the tax under chapter 1, the tax under chapter 2, and the tax under chapter 2A for such taxable year the sum of the amounts determined under paragraph (2) for each day for which there is an underpayment.
The amount determined under this paragraph for any day shall be the product of—

subparagraph.text: the underpayment rate established under subsection (b)(2) for such day, multiplied by
the amount of the underpayment for such day.

subsection.text: For purposes of subsection (a)—

paragraph.text: The amount of underpayment on any day shall be the excess (if any) of—

subparagraph.text: the sum of the required installments for the taxable year the due dates for which are on or before such day, over
the sum of the amounts of estimated tax payments made for such taxable year on or before such day.

The underpayment rate with respect to any day in an installment underpayment period shall be the underpayment rate established under section 6621 for the first day of the calendar quarter in which such installment underpayment period begins.

For purposes of subparagraph (A), the term installment underpayment period means the period beginning on the day after the due date for a required installment and ending on the due date for the subsequent required installment (or in the case of the 4th required installment, the 15th day of the 4th month following the close of a taxable year).
The rate determined under subparagraph (A) shall be applied on a daily basis and shall be based on the assumption of 365 days in a calendar year.

paragraph.text: No day after the end of the installment underpayment period for the 4th required installment specified in paragraph (2)(B) for a taxable year shall be treated as a day of underpayment with respect to such taxable year.

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2015.

section.header: Corporate estimated tax

subsection.header: Increase in Small Tax Amount Exception
subsection.text: Section 6655(f) is amended by striking $500 and inserting $1,000.
The amendment made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2015.

section.header: Increase in large corporation threshold for estimated tax payments

subsection.text: Section 6655(g)(2) is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking $1,000,000 in subparagraph (A) and inserting the applicable amount,
by striking the $1,000,000 amount specified in subparagraph (A) in subparagraph (B)(ii) and inserting the applicable amount,
by redesignating subparagraph (B) as subparagraph (C), and
by inserting after subparagraph (A) the following new subparagraph:

subparagraph.text: For purposes of this paragraph, the applicable amount is $1,000,000 increased (but not above $1,500,000) by $50,000 for each taxable year beginning after 2015.

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2015.

section.header: Expansion of interest netting

subsection.text: Subsection (d) of section 6621 is amended by adding at the end the following new sentence: Solely for purposes of the preceding sentence, section 6611(e) shall not apply..
The amendment made by this section shall apply to interest accrued after December 31, 2015.

section.header: Clarification of application of Federal tax deposit penalty
section.text: Nothing in section 6656 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 shall be construed to permit the percentage specified in subsection (b)(1)(A)(iii) thereof to apply other than in a case where the failure is for more than 15 days.

section.header: Collection activities with respect to joint return disclosable to either spouse based on oral request

subsection.text: Paragraph (8) of section 6103(e) is amended by striking in writing the first place it appears.
The amendment made by this section shall apply to requests made after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Disclosure of taxpayer identity for tax refund purposes
section.text: Section 6103(m)(1) is amended by striking taxpayer identity information to the press and other media and by inserting a person’s name and the city and State of the person’s mailing address to the press, other media, and through any other means of mass communication,.

section.header: Release of information regarding the status of certain investigations

subsection.text: Subsection (e) of section 6103 is amended by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

paragraph.header: Disclosure to certain relevant persons of information regarding status of certain investigations

subparagraph.text: With respect to any investigation conducted by the officers and employees of the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration which relates to possible violations of the internal revenue laws or related statutes, the Secretary and the Attorney General may, upon written request by any relevant person, disclose to such person (or such person's designee)—

clause.text: whether there is or has been such an investigation with respect to which such person is a relevant person, and
if there is or has been such an investigation—

subclause.text: whether such investigation is on-going or has been completed, and

if such investigation has been completed, the conclusions of such investigation, including whether there was a referral to administrative authorities or for criminal prosecution, and the contact information of the person handling the referred matter.

subparagraph.text: Not later than 30 days after the completion of any investigation—

clause.text: which is conducted by the officers and employees of the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration, and
the results of which indicate that—

subclause.text: there is substantial evidence that there has been a violation of the internal revenue laws or related statutes, and
such violation involves one or more relevant persons,

subparagraph.continuation-text: the Secretary shall disclose to all such relevant persons (or designees) the conclusions of the investigation, including whether there was a referral to administrative authorities or for criminal prosecution, and the contact information of the person handling the referred matter.

subparagraph.text: For purposes of this paragraph, the term relevant person means, with respect to any investigation—

clause.text: any complainant who provided information to the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration related to the investigation, and
any taxpayer who is directly connected with the matter being investigated.

subsection.text: The amendment made by this section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Mandatory electronic filing for annual returns of exempt organizations

subsection.text: Section 6033 is amended by redesignating subsection (n) as subsection (o) and by inserting after subsection (m) the following new subsection:
Any organization required to file a return under this section shall file such return in electronic form.

subsection.header: Inspection of electronically filed annual returns
subsection.text: Subsection (b) of section 6104 is amended by adding at the end the following: Any annual return required to be filed electronically under section 6033(n) shall be made available by the Secretary to the public in machine readable format as soon as practicable..

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2), the amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act.

clause.text: In the case of any small organizations, or any other organizations for which the Secretary determines the application of the amendments made by subsection (a) would cause undue burden without a delay, the Secretary may delay the application of such amendments, but not later than taxable years beginning 2 years after the date of the enactment of this Act.
For purposes of clause (i), the term small organization means any organization—

subclause.text: the gross receipts of which for the taxable year are less than $200,000, and
the aggregate gross assets of which at the end of the taxable year are less than $500,000.

subparagraph.text: In the case of any organization described in section 511(a)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 which is subject to the tax imposed by section 511(a)(1) of such Code on its unrelated business taxable income, or any organization required to file a return under section 6033 of such Code and include information under subsection (e) thereof, the Secretary may delay the application of the amendments made by this section, but not later than taxable years beginning 2 years after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Free electronic filing

subsection.text: The Secretary of the Treasury (or the Secretary's delegate) shall, in cooperation with the private sector technology industry, maintain a program that provides free individual income tax preparation and electronic filing services to low-income taxpayers and elderly taxpayers.
The Secretary shall by regulation or other guidance prescribe with respect to the program—

paragraph.text: the qualifications, selection process, and contract term for businesses participating in the program,
a process for periodic review of businesses participating in the program,
procedures for terminating business participation in the program for failure to comply with any program requirements, and
such other procedures as the Secretary determines are necessary or appropriate to carry out the purposes of the program.

subsection.text: The Internal Revenue Service Free File program, as set forth in the notice published in the Federal Register on November 4, 2002 (67 Fed. Reg. 67247), shall be treated as meeting the requirements of subsection (a).

section.header: Access to appeals
section.text: Subsection (b) of section 3465 of the Internal Revenue Service Restructuring and Reform Act of 1998 is amended by striking an appeals officer is regularly available within each State and inserting there is at least one appeals officer and one settlement officer located and permanently available in each State, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico.
